Award.AwardTitle: GK-12: Graduate Fellows in Science and Mathematics Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
PROPOSAL #: 0637027
PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: Carmen Latterell
INSTITUTION: University of Minnesota Duluth
TITLE: GK-12: Graduate Fellows in Science and Mathematics Education


The Graduate Fellows in Science and Mathematics Education, a GK-12 project between the University of Minnesota Duluth and four K-12 schools, focuses on defining the needs and limitations for improving STEM teaching and on creating innovative instruction for students using inquiry-based learning processes in mathematics, biology and geology. Project activities include a summer workshop, a seminar series, as well as ongoing communication using ePortfolio and WebCT. The intellectual merit of this project for fellows include 1) learning inquiry-based pedagogy to teach STEM knowledge and skills, 2) an appreciation of the challenges, rewards and needs of K-12 education, 3) developing and sharing effective methods of scientific communication to a non-technical audience and 4) becoming effective and critically reflective teachers of STEM. K-12 teachers will 1) strengthen their STEM and technical knowledge 2) engage students in authentic science and math inquiry-based learning, 3) gain resources/equipment for authentic learning, 4) enhance their repertoire of teaching through mentoring the fellows, and 5) develop partnerships with the University faculty and graduate fellows. The K-12 students will 1) learn about scientific and mathematics inquiry, 2) gain proficiency, confidence and interest in science and mathematics, and 3) be aware of the career choices for scientists and mathematicians. This project includes efforts to broaden participation of underrepresented groups such as Native Americans. Participants of the project will disseminate information and experiences with colleagues locally, regionally and nationally. A strong working partnership will be developed between the University faculty, K-12 teachers, students and parents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Minnesota Duluth was awarded a five-year grant to implement and run the Math and Science Graduate Fellows in K12 Education Program. For the years 2007-2012, 49 math and/or science graduate fellows were placed in local schools to be the face of math/science. In addition, these graduate fellows conducted inquiry lessons in the classrooms and worked with a teacher to conduct action research projects.

 

At the end of five years, the teachers reported numerous examples of how the presence of fellows in their classrooms refreshed their ability to create lessons, which immersed students in inquiry-based science and math. As one teacher put it, students were able to “See it live” as fellows progressed through their research projects and shared the process and results with students. Teachers also recognized that students responded differently to the fellows’ inquiry based lessons. One teacher related how students often don’t retain learning for long periods of time; yet they distinctly remembered ideas taught by fellows back to the beginning of the school year. Teachers also reported an increase in their content knowledge and ability to explore current science/math literature and research.

 

The fellows also benefitted from the project, with an increase in their ability to communicate with young people and general audiences about science/math topics. One fellow remarked that the experience of learning to communicate with general audiences made him a better scientist. The evidence collected over the course of the project indicates that fellows’ communications skills have increased.

 

The action research projects also resulted in permanent outcomes. The projects themselves contributed to the general research and knowledge base of K-12 teaching and learning. For example, one of the projects involved how to help students overcome mathematics anxiety. The projects also helped the involved K-12 students. One project taught a large group of students how to take effective classroom notes. This is a skill that will follow those students through post-secondary education. Perhaps the largest gain from the action research projects, however, was to thoroughly establish with the fellows what the issues and challenges are in K-12 education. Past fellows are already strong advocates for K-12 education in their current communities.

 

In addition, lessons learned from this project have already contributed to the understanding of professional development for science and math educators. The project manager for the project has already utilized his new understandings in applications to other grant applications, and in delivering methods courses to pre-service K-12 science educators. Other members of the project team have also had success in bringing educational tools to the broader university community.
